techniques.name: XRD
techniques.parameters: 2θ = 10–80° or 10–140°, step size 0.04°, counting time 4 s/step

challenge.description: Irreversible phase transition from orthorhombic LiMnO2 to spinel LiMn2O4 and rock salt Li0.5Mn0.5O during cycling.
challenge.impact: This phase transition critically impacts charge and discharge capacity and cycle life, reducing the material's effectiveness as a cathode.

solution.description: High-resolution XRD was employed to study phase transitions and refine structural details, revealing the coexistence of spinel and rock salt phases upon further cycling.
solution.methodology: Use of high-resolution XRD and Rietveld refinement to analyze structural changes and quantify phase ratios.
solution.effectiveness: The solution provided detailed insights into the phase transition but did not prevent the structural changes; further studies are needed to address the electrochemical behavior of the rock salt phase.

evidence.source: Results and discussion section, Figures 4 and 6, Table 1
evidence.data: XRD patterns showing disappearance of orthorhombic peaks and appearance of spinel and rock salt peaks after three cycles; phase ratios of 88.9% spinel and 11.1% rock salt determined.

context.material_properties: Orthorhombic LiMnO2 has a theoretical capacity of 285 mAh g−1 but undergoes structural changes during cycling.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling at 0.1 C rate between 2.0–4.5 V at 25°C.
context.application_relevance: The material is intended for use as a cathode in rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, where phase stability is critical for performance.

challenge.description: Formation of rock salt phase is dependent on cycling rate, with higher current densities leading to larger quantities of rock salt structure.
challenge.impact: Higher current densities hinder structural reordering of rock salt phase to spinel, potentially reducing battery performance.

solution.description: Analysis of phase abundance at different current densities to understand the relationship between cycling rate and rock salt formation.
solution.methodology: Quantitative phase analysis using Rietveld refinement and XRD measurements at varying current densities.
solution.effectiveness: The study clarified the dependency of rock salt formation on cycling rate but did not propose a method to mitigate the issue; further research is needed.

evidence.source: Results and discussion section, Figure 7, Table 1
evidence.data: Phase abundance data showing increased rock salt formation at higher current densities; structural parameters of rock salt phase determined.

context.material_properties: Rock salt Li0.5Mn0.5O has a cell parameter of 4.121 Å and coexists with spinel phase during cycling.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling at varying current densities with voltage window of 2.0–4.5 V.
context.application_relevance: Understanding rock salt formation is crucial for optimizing cycling conditions and improving battery performance.

challenge.description: Spinel structure exhibits cationic disorder, with about 9% of Li positions occupied by Mn and vice versa.
challenge.impact: Cationic disorder may affect electrochemical behavior and stability compared to the ordered phase.

solution.description: Detailed structural analysis using XRD and Rietveld refinement to characterize cationic disorder and its potential impact on electrochemical properties.
solution.methodology: High-resolution XRD and refinement techniques to quantify cationic disorder and analyze its effects.
solution.effectiveness: The analysis provided valuable insights into the disorder's role in improving electrochemical behavior but did not address how to control or optimize the disorder.

evidence.data: Structural parameters showing cationic disorder in spinel phase; occupancy data for Li and Mn sites.

context.material_properties: Spinel LiMn2O4 has a cell parameter of 8.241 Å and displays cationic disorder on Li and Mn sites.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling at 0.1 C rate with voltage window of 2.0–4.5 V.
context.application_relevance: Cationic disorder may enhance electrochemical behavior, making the spinel phase more tolerant to repeated lithium insertion and extraction.
